description: Second pass of intellectual genealogy: scans a single prior work for genealogical connections to the current work. ADAPTS analysis strategy based on the relationship classification from Pass 1B. For direct precursors: traces specific ideas. For indirect contextualizers: identifies foundational patterns and intellectual toolkits. For different-field works: detects cross-domain transfers. For counter-positions: analyzes reversals. Runs ONCE PER PRIOR WORK.
researcher_question: What genealogical connections — direct traces, foundational patterns, cross-domain transfers, or position reversals — exist between this prior work and the current work?

prior_work_info.title: string - title of the prior work being scanned
prior_work_info.context: string - what this work was about and its intellectual context
prior_work_info.relationship_type: direct_precursor | indirect_contextualizer | different_field_relevant | counter_position | tangential - as classified by Pass 1B

traces_found.target_idea_name: string - name of the target idea for readability
traces_found.description: string - how this idea appears in the prior work

textual_evidence.quote: string - direct quote from the prior work
textual_evidence.location: string - approximate location in the prior work

traces_found.notable_differences: string - how the prior version differs from the current version
traces_found.function_in_prior_work: string - what role this idea played in the prior argument

ideas_not_found.idea_id: string - target idea_id not found in this prior work
ideas_not_found.idea_name: string - name of the absent idea
ideas_not_found.significance_of_absence: string - what it means that this idea wasn't present yet

foundational_patterns.pattern_name: string - concise name for this foundational pattern
foundational_patterns.pattern_description: string - what this thinking pattern, analytical method, or cognitive habit consists of
foundational_patterns.how_it_enables_current_work: string - how this pattern enables, shapes, or informs the current work's arguments, even if the author doesn't consciously deploy it

textual_evidence_prior.quote: string - quote from the prior work showing this pattern

foundational_patterns.manifestation_in_current_work: string - where and how this pattern appears (perhaps transformed) in the current work
foundational_patterns.pattern_type: analytical_method | cognitive_habit | recurring_metaphor | problem_solving_approach | theoretical_framework | argumentative_structure | epistemic_commitment
foundational_patterns.author_awareness: explicit | implicit | unconscious - whether the author seems aware of deploying this pattern from their earlier work

cross_domain_transfers.source_domain: string - the domain of the prior work
cross_domain_transfers.target_domain: string - the domain of the current work
cross_domain_transfers.what_transferred: string - what method, framework, metaphor, or structural analogy was imported
cross_domain_transfers.how_transformed: string - how the transferred element was adapted for the new domain
cross_domain_transfers.validity_of_transfer: string - whether the cross-domain move is analytically justified or introduces distortions
cross_domain_transfers.blind_spots_created: string - what the author's expertise in the source domain causes them to miss or distort in the target domain
cross_domain_transfers.unique_insights_enabled: string - what the cross-domain perspective uniquely reveals

positions_reversed.prior_position: string - what the author argued before
positions_reversed.current_position: string - what the author argues now
positions_reversed.evidence_prior: string - quote or reference from prior work
positions_reversed.evidence_current: string - quote or reference from current work
positions_reversed.how_managed: string - does the author acknowledge, explain, minimize, or ignore the reversal?
positions_reversed.what_drove_change: string - hypothesized reason for the shift

reversal_analysis.continuities_despite_reversal: string - what remains consistent even as positions changed

new_discoveries.discovery: string - ideas in the prior work that are relevant but weren't in our target list
new_discoveries.relevance: string - why this discovery matters for the genealogical analysis

meta.relationship_type: string - the classified relationship type from Pass 1B
meta.analysis_strategy_used: string - which analysis approach was applied based on the relationship type
meta.coverage_ratio: number (0-1) - for direct_precursor: fraction of target ideas found. For other types: fraction of meaningful connections identified relative to potential
key_findings: string - notable observations about this prior work's relationship to the current work

extraction.core_question: What genealogical connections exist between this prior work and the current work, given the classified relationship type?
extraction_steps: RECEIVE CONTEXT: Review the target ideas from Pass 1 AND the relationship classification from Pass 1B. The classification tells you what kind of prior work this is and what to look for.
ADAPT STRATEGY BASED ON RELATIONSHIP TYPE:
--- IF DIRECT PRECURSOR: Follow the standard genealogical trace approach ---
SCAN FOR EACH IDEA: Systematically search the prior work for traces of each target idea
CLASSIFY FORM: For each trace found, determine its form — proto_form, full_form, contradictory_form, absent_but_implied, or different_framing
ASSESS DIFFERENCES: Note how the prior version differs from the current version
DOCUMENT FUNCTION: Record what role this idea played in the prior argument
NOTE ABSENCES: Record ideas not present and assess significance
Populate: traces_found, ideas_not_found, new_discoveries. Leave foundational_patterns, cross_domain_transfers, reversal_analysis empty or minimal.
--- IF INDIRECT CONTEXTUALIZER: Focus on foundational thinking patterns ---
DO NOT search for direct traces of specific ideas (they won't be there — that's the point)

Instead: IDENTIFY FOUNDATIONAL PATTERNS — analytical methods, cognitive habits, recurring metaphors, problem-solving approaches, theoretical frameworks, argumentative structures, or epistemic commitments in this prior work
For each pattern: trace how it ENABLES the current work's arguments, even if the author doesn't consciously deploy it
Assess AUTHOR AWARENESS: Does the author realize they're using this toolkit from their earlier work, or is it unconscious?
Populate: foundational_patterns primarily. traces_found may have a few entries if any direct connections exist. ideas_not_found should note that absence is EXPECTED for this relationship type.
--- IF DIFFERENT FIELD RELEVANT: Focus on cross-domain transfer ---
IDENTIFY what methods, frameworks, metaphors, or structural analogies the author imports from the prior work's domain into the current work's domain
ASSESS VALIDITY: Is the cross-domain transfer analytically justified, or does it introduce distortions?
IDENTIFY BLIND SPOTS: What does expertise in the source domain cause the author to miss in the target domain?
IDENTIFY UNIQUE INSIGHTS: What does the cross-domain perspective uniquely reveal?
Populate: cross_domain_transfers primarily, plus any foundational_patterns.
--- IF COUNTER POSITION: Focus on reversals and shifts ---
IDENTIFY specific positions that were reversed or significantly modified
CLASSIFY the nature of each shift: full_reversal, significant_modification, subtle_drift, or recontextualization
ASSESS MANAGEMENT: How does the author handle the reversal — acknowledge, explain, minimize, or ignore?
IDENTIFY what drove the change
NOTE what remains consistent despite the reversals
Populate: reversal_analysis primarily, plus any traces_found for ideas that persist in modified form.
--- IF TANGENTIAL: Minimal analysis ---
Brief scan for any unexpected connections. If truly tangential, document why and keep analysis short.
Populate: meta with explanation, minimal other fields.
ALWAYS: Flag any new discoveries not captured by the target idea list

key_fields.trace_id: Unique identifier for each genealogical trace (direct precursors)
key_fields.pattern_id: Unique identifier for each foundational pattern (indirect contextualizers)
key_fields.transfer_id: Unique identifier for each cross-domain transfer (different-field works)
key_fields.reversal_id: Unique identifier for each position reversal (counter-positions)
key_fields.form_in_prior_work: How the idea manifests in the prior work
key_fields.confidence: How confident we are in this trace

extraction.special_instructions: CRITICAL: Your analysis strategy MUST be determined by the relationship_type classification provided. Do not treat all prior works the same way. A game theory textbook by the author should NOT be scanned for direct traces of technofeudalism ideas — it should be scanned for the foundational thinking patterns (strategic reasoning, information asymmetry analysis, etc.) that later enable the technofeudalism argument. Conversely, a direct precursor work SHOULD be scanned for specific idea traces. Match your approach to the relationship type. When in doubt about which fields to populate, use the recommended_analysis_focus from the Pass 1B classification.

consolidation_rules: Group foundational patterns by pattern type
Flag contradictory forms as high priority for evolution analysis
Flag foundational patterns with unconscious author_awareness as especially significant

id_examples.to: Proto-form of 'functional economy' in earlier automation analysis
Strategic reasoning framework from game theory enabling market power analysis
Nash equilibrium thinking imported from game theory to platform economics
Reversal from 'capitalism can be saved' to 'capitalism is already dead'

concretization.naming_guidance: Use trace form + target idea name for direct precursors; pattern name + how it enables for indirect contextualizers; transfer type for cross-domain; reversal description for counter-positions
